{{use American English|date=August 2015}} {{use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} The '''Harper Novel Prize''' was an award presented by [[Harper_(publisher)|Harper Brothers]], an American publishing company located in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]].
The award was presented to the best [[novel]] by an "unnoticed" writer.{{clarify|date=August 2015|reason=were candidates for the award restricted to Harper Brothers novels?}}<ref>[http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1936/3/18/harper-prize-novel-contest-is-announced]. ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''. March 18, 1936.</ref> A number of the awarded books went on to win the [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] and many were [[Film adaptation|adapted into films]].
==Winners== Winners of the Harper Prize included:<ref>[http://centerforfiction.org/awards/the-flaherty-dunnan-first-novel-prize/previous-first-novel-prize-short-lists/], The Center for Fiction First Novel Prize, Previous Winners. Retrieved November 27, 2011.</ref> * 1922–1923: [[Margaret Wilson (writer)|Margaret Wilson]], ''[[The Able McLaughlins]]''<ref name=sept2>[https://www.nytimes.com/1923/09/02/archives/books-and-authors.html "Books and Authors"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. September 2, 1923. Retrieved August 5, 2010.</ref><ref>[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D1FFA345C167B93C0AB1788D85F428385F9 "Books and Authors"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. March 22, 1936. Retrieved August 5, 2010.</ref> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * 1925: [[Anne Parrish]], ''[[The Perennial Bachelor]]'' * 1927: [[Glenway Wescott]], ''[[The Grandmothers: A Family Portrait]]'' * 1929: [[Julien Green]], ''[[Leviathan (Green novel)|Leviathan]]'' * 1931: [[Robert Raynolds]], ''[[Brothers in the West]]'' * 1933: [[Paul Horgan]], ''[[The Fault of Angels]]'' * 1935: [[Harold Lenoir Davis]], ''[[Honey in the Horn]]'' * 1937: [[Frederic Prokosch]], ''[[The Seven Who Fled]]'' * 1939: [[Vardis Fisher]], ''[[Children of God (Fisher novel)|Children of God]]'' * 1941: [[Judith Kelly (novelist)|Judith Kelly]], ''[[Marriage Is a Private Affair (novel)|Marriage Is a Private Affair]]'' * 1943: [[Martin Flavin]], ''[[Journey in the Dark]]'' * 1945: [[Jo Sinclair]], ''[[Wasteland (Sinclair novel)|Wasteland]]'' * 1947: [[Joseph Hitrec]], ''[[Son of the Moon]]'' * 1949: [[Max Steele (novelist)|Max Steele]], ''[[Debby (novel)|Debby]]'' * 1955: [[Don Mankiewicz]], ''[[Trial (novel)|Trial]]'' * 1957: [[Frank Norris (novelist)|Frank Norris]], ''[[Tower in the West]]'' * 1959: [[Robin White (novelist)|Robin White]], ''[[Elephant Hill]]'' * 1963: [[Richard McKenna]], ''[[The Sand Pebbles]]'' * 1965: [[C. D. B. Bryan]], ''[[P.S. Wilkinson]]'' {{div col end}}

{{good article}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Chinese name|[[Huang (surname)|Wong]] (黃)}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Kacey Wong | image = Kacey Wong, 2014 (cropped).jpg | imagesize = 180px | caption = Kacey Wong in 2014. | birth_name = | birth_date = 1970 | birth_place = Hong Kong | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = | nationality = Hong Kong Chinese | field = Visual arts, architecture, sculpture | training = [[Cornell University]] (architecture); [[Chelsea College of Arts]] (sculpture); [[Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]] (fine arts)<ref name=polyukacey/> | movement = | works = ''Drift City'' (2000), ''Wandering Home'', (2008), ''Paddling Home'' (2009) | patrons = | awards = | module = {{Chinese |child=yes |title=Kacey Wong |t=黃國才 |s=黃国才 |p=Huáng Guócái |showorder=tsp |w= |mi= |y= |j=Wong4 Gwok3 Choi4 }} | website = {{URL|kaceywong.com}} }}
'''Kacey Wong''' (born 1970) is a [[Hong Kong people|Hong Kong]] visual artist and educator<ref name=20130129goasia>{{cite web|url=http://www.go.asia/eco-drum-to-voice-sustainability/|title=Eco Drum to Voice Sustainability|date=29 January 2013|work=go.asia}}</ref> – formerly Assistant Professor at the School of Design, [[Hong Kong Polytechnic University]].<ref name=polyukacey>{{cite web|url=http://www.sd.polyu.edu.hk/en/meet-our-staff/kaceywong|title=PolyU Design: Kacey Kwok-choi Wong|publisher=PolyU Design|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095855/http://www.sd.polyu.edu.hk/en/meet-our-staff/kaceywong|archivedate=2 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="arts-news.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.arts-news.net/articles/2014/11/13/%E6%8A%97%E7%88%AD%E7%8F%BE%E5%A0%B4%E6%90%9E%E8%97%9D%E8%A1%93%EF%BC%8C%E6%89%80%E7%82%BA%E4%BD%95%E4%BA%8B%EF%BC%9F%E2%80%94%E9%BB%83%E5%9C%8B%E6%89%8D%E8%88%87%E4%BF%9E%E8%8B%A5%E7%8E%AB%E8%AB%87%E6%8A%97%E7%88%AD%E8%97%9D%E8%A1%93|script-title=zh:抗爭現場搞藝術，所為何事？—黃國才與俞若玫談抗爭藝術|date=13 November 2014|work=藝頻：藝術推廣新聞頻道先導計劃|language=zh}}</ref> Wong has received the Hong Kong Contemporary Arts Award by the [[Hong Kong Art Museum]] (2012), Best Artist Award (2010); and Rising Artist Award and Outstanding Arts Education Award (2003).<ref name=ecozine/>
== Early life and education == Wong Kwok-choi was born in 1970 in Hong Kong. Due to concerns about the future of Hong Kong at the time, Wong was sent away at the age of 14 to Long Island in the United States as a secondary school pupil.<ref name=20140309mingpao>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150402131033/http://www.ol.mingpao.com/cfm/style5.cfm?File=20140309%2Fsta13%2Fuaa1.txt "生活達人﹕以抗爭藝術復修家園"]. ''Ming Pao'', 9 March 2014 {{zh icon}} Archived from the [http://www.ol.mingpao.com/cfm/style5.cfm?File=20140309/sta13/uaa1.txt original] on 2 April 2015</ref><ref name=whatsnext/> His chosen name "Kacey" is derived from the initials of his Chinese name.<ref name=2011raw/> Wong was admitted to [[Cornell University]], from where he obtained a bachelor's degree in Architecture.<ref name=muse>Cha, Sylvia. "Building Dreams / 看透是一種藝術 – A look at 黃國才 (Kacey Wong)s delicate works", ''[[Muse (Hong Kong magazine)|Muse]]'' (2008),</ref> He has practiced internationally as an architect and artist. His sculptures explore philosophical ideas that engage the body of the viewer. He holds a master's degree in Sculpture at [[Chelsea College of Arts]].<ref name=polyukacey/><ref name=20140309mingpao/><ref name=whatsnext/> Wong also obtained his Doctorate in Fine Arts from the [[Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]] in 2003.<ref name=polyukacey/>
== Career == Upon graduation from university, Wong worked as an architect for nearly six years in New York, Japan, and Hong Kong, in the fields of graphic, interior and architectural design. He set up in independent practice.<ref name=muse/> Finding that the professional world as an architect did not allow for the degree of freedom he desired, he gave up a well-paid professional career and left for further studies in England.<ref name=20140309mingpao/><ref name=muse/> After finishing the masters programme in London in 1998, Wong returned to Hong Kong and taught sculpture and art appreciation at the [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]] for two years.<ref name=muse/><ref>"Cover story". ''iMag'', 3 November 2000, pg. 8.</ref> Wong later became Assistant professor in the school of design at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University, until 2015.<ref name=polyukacey/><ref name=muse/>
In 2003, Wong was bestowed the Rising Artist Award by the Hong Kong Arts Council and Outstanding Arts Education Award.<ref name=polyukacey/> The [[Hong Kong Museum of Art]] awarded Wong their Hong Kong Contemporary Arts Award in 2012.<ref name=ecozine/>
== Works == Wong stated that most people take for granted what they possess, and may be without identity or culture. Wong says his self-awareness, and what Hong Kong represents to him, stem from the years he spent abroad. He says that only by living amidst a second culture can one fully come to realise what one represents and where one belongs. A thread that runs through much of his work is therefore the notion of home, homelessness and wandering.<ref name=20140309mingpao/><ref name=2011raw>[http://issuu.com/rawmagazine/docs/rawmagazinefinalonline?mode=window&viewMode=doublePage "Kacey Wong is 'Superbeast'"]. ''Raw Magazine'', No. 1. December 2011</ref> Since 2011, his repertoire has taken on a political dimension.
=== Space === ''Home'' (1999), ''Personal Skyscraper'' (2000), and ''City Space'' (2001) were exhibitions where Wong was both exhibitor and curator.
"10 Boxes: Everything I've Ever Thought About, I Put Inside a Box" in 2000 was Wong's first solo exhibition. The series of ten sculptures, housed in wall-mounted boxes, each having its own name, explores a different theme or spatial relationship.<ref>Thomas, Ralph (21 April 2000). "Box of tricks". ''South China Morning Post''.</ref> For example, ''Office Block'' symbolises the power structures within companies; ''Only You'' is based on romantic relations; ''Destroy Them'' treats subjects like education and childhood influences.<ref>Binks, Hilary. "Boxed In". ''World Sculpture News'' (spring 2000)</ref>
In 2008, Wong created ''Wandering Home'', an installation consisting of a mobile home conceptualised on city living and the homeless, which was shown at the [[Venice Biennale of Architecture]].<ref name=20091115singtao>"「大鐵人」反思港人蝸居苦". ''Sing Tao Daily'', 15 November 2009 {{zh icon}}</ref> The small tin hut on the back of a tricycle is a comment on Hong Kong society, and the plight of people who sleep on the streets and who are forced to move on periodically by government officials. Costing HK$5,000 to make, the house is not exactly a practical solution to the homeless, but the concept was tried out on street sleepers in [[Sham Shui Po]].<ref>"Mobilizing the Homeless", pg. HK-4, ''China Daily'' (Hong Kong edition), 24 January 2008</ref><ref>"三個車轆裝起流浪的心", pg. A26. ''Ming Pao'', 4 January 2008 {{zh icon}}</ref><ref>Lai, Ying-kit (4 January 2008). "Tricycle mobile home offers little comfort for the homeless". ''South China Morning Post''</ref> In 2008, Wong created ''Tin Man No.11'', an essay in space in the form of a metallic robot that transforms into a bed.<ref name=whatsnext>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsnext30x30.com/guest-artists/kacey-wong/|title=KACEY WONG黄国才 |publisher=whatsnext30x30.com|language=zh}}</ref> He extended the concept by creating ''Famiglia Grande'', a series of transformable cases.<ref name=20091115singtao/><ref>"一個流動豪宅之夢／Kacey Wong Dream of Street Sleepers", ''AM 730''. 12 April 2010 {{zh icon}}</ref><ref>"I, Robot", ''Plan Magazine'', March 2010</ref><ref>"Morar dentro de um carro", ''Sabado'', 22 April 2010 {{pt icon}}</ref> In 2009, Wong attended the Subvision Festival in Hamburg as a skyscraper.<ref name=time2008795>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2008795,00.html|title=An Art Boom in Hong Kong|date=16 August 2010|work=Time}}</ref>
His work ''Paddling Home'', a {{convert|4|x|4|ft|abbr=on}} floating house, was set to sea in January 2010. The work, symbolising the Hong Kong's property market where the accommodation is high-density, small and pricey, was selected at the Hong Kong & Shenzhen Bi City Biennale of Urbanism Architecture exhibition that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/supplement/culture/art/20100121/13646972|title=Two Men Show展場：海|date=21 January 2010|work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mpaper.org/Story.aspx?ID=470103|script-title=zh:以藝術呈現樓市的迷思 |date=24 September 2013|work=Macau Daily|language=zh}}</ref> The design includes tiled walls, wooden floorboards, bay windows, a television, air-conditioning, roof space from which to drive a few golf balls and a 5-horsepower outboard motor.<ref>"Il était un petit... houseboat". ''Moteur Boat'', Oct 2010, pp. 22–23 {{fr icon}}</ref><ref>DeWolf, Christopher (17 January 2010). "Art show that's struggling to stay afloat", pg. 3, ''South China Morning Post''</ref> It was priced at a [[Numbers in Chinese culture#Eight|symbolical HK$888,888]] ($114,000). Wong said that, as the square foot price is [an astronomical] HK$55,555, ''Paddling Home'' is an ironic statement comparing the perils of owning a glitzily- and glossily-packaged high end residence to being on the high seas.<ref>"16方尺漂流屋「售」88.8888萬". ''Sing Tao Daily'', 4 December 2009 {{zh icon}}</ref> When asked in 2012, Wong said he considers ''Paddling Home'' his most challenging work to date.<ref>"Kacey Wong", ''Time Out'' (Hong Kong). 9–22 May 2012, pg 24.</ref>
[[File:Ballball.jpg|thumb|190px|''Ball Ball'' (2014)]] He published a photographic book, ''Drift City 2000–2010'', as the culmination of a ten-year project where he travelled the world and superposed himself as a cardboard skyscraper (Skyscraper Man) in different surroundings as a critique of modernism.<ref name=headline92806>[http://hd.stheadline.com/beauty/beauty_content.asp?contid=92806&srctype=g "紙皮大廈披上身 黃國才十載遊離都市"]. Headline News. ''Sing Tao Daily'', 20 December 2010 {{zh icon}}</ref> For the project, Wong collected images from over 20 locations around the world, including one at the Egyptian pyramids made when he and his wife were on honeymoon in 2002. That image cost him a three-hour art lecture to police who demanded a substantial "photography fee".<ref name=headline92806/>
=== Environmentalism === Wong became interested in environmentalism through visiting a waste reprocessing centre in Hong Kong, and realising just how little was recycled. His works re-use or recycle materials obtained from rubbish tips.<ref name=20130129goasia/><ref name=ecozine/> In 2010, Wong curated "Memory of the Forest", a collection of animal sculptures by himself and 13 students made using discarded wood, which symbolises the animals' lost habitats.<ref name=2011raw/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://programme.rthk.hk/rthk/tv/programme.php?name=tv/theworks&d=2010-05-11&p=2453&e=108455&m=episode|date=11 May 2010|title=The Works :Ai Weiwei in Hong Kong; Movie Review – "Iron Man 2"; Hong Kong Turkish Film Festival; "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead"; "Memory of the Forest"|publisher=RTHK}}</ref><ref>"香港雕塑發展新貌", AM 730. 31 May 2010 {{zh icon}}</ref><ref>"黃國才", ''U Magazine'', April 2010 {{zh icon}}</ref> Wong contributed a similar "Mega Musical Art Piece" to the 2012 Hong Kong Cleanup campaign in the form of an octopus.<ref name=20130129goasia/><ref>[http://www.hkcleanup.org/en/content/hong-kong-cleanup-exhibit "The Hong Kong Cleanup Exhibit"]. Hong Kong Cleanup, 18 January 2013</ref> Wong participated in a campaign of the [[Ocean Recovery Alliance]] in Hong Kong in April 2013, contributing ''Death by Amputation'' – a sculpture of a life-sized [[Shark finning|finned shark]] – to an exhibition in [[Stanley, Hong Kong|Stanley]] harbour in the hope that it will provoke thought on the source of food and the cruelty inflicted by humans on animals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1210975/ocean-film-festival-conjures-goddess-sharks|title=Ocean film festival conjures up goddess of sharks|work=South China Morning Post| date=10 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/realtime/news/20130409/51338681|script-title=zh:垃圾升華變藝術 另類保育海洋 |date=9 April 2013|work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref><ref>"廢材藝術品喚醒保育海洋". pg. 46. Headline News (Hong Kong), 19 April 2013</ref> In 2014, as part of an animal-themed exhibition with other artists, he unveiled ''Ball Ball'', an imposing sculpture of his one-eyed cat again made of discarded wood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artasiapacific.com/Magazine/WebExclusives/HongKongBestiary|title=Hong Kong Bestiary|date=November 2014|publisher=ArtAsiaPacific}}</ref> {{clear}}[[File:Culture bureau.jpg|thumb|190px|Wong's ''The Cultural Bureau'' leading 1 July 2012 protest march]]
=== Protest art === Wong cites his political awakening being in 2011, following the arrest of mainland artist [[Ai Weiwei]].<ref name=20140309mingpao/><ref name=artnet273789/> He responded by forming a group named Art Citizens (藝術公民), and rallied some 2,000 artists to march for Ai on 23 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/05/04/135985475/hong-kong-graffiti-challenges-chinese-artists-arrest|title=Hong Kong Graffiti Challenges Chinese Artist's Arrest|date=4 May 2011|publisher=NPR}}</ref><ref name=apple18878618/> As curator for the group, he put together a month-long exhibition that opened on 26 May named "Love the Future" (愛未來) – a pun on Ai's name – with works of over 50 artists.<ref name=henders> {{cite book |last1=Jim |first1=Alice Ming-Wai |date= |year=2014 |orig-year= |chapter=Love the Future – Ai Weiwei and Art for Human Rights |editor1-last=Henders |editor1-first=Susan J.|editor1-link= |editor2-last=Cho|editor2-first=Lily |title=Human Rights and the Arts: Perspectives on Global Asia |trans-title= |url=https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=HJMYBQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Human+Rights+and+the+Arts:+Perspectives+on+Global+Asia%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5hAOVZOIH5bs8AWNuoCACQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=kacey%20wong&f=false |publisher= Lexington Books|publication-date= |pages=33–35 |isbn=978-0739184738 }}</ref><ref name=pages31to41>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/stevenriver/docs/10issue009|title=愛未來 Love the Future Exhibition|issue=009 |author=Steven River|pages=31–47|work=Issuu – 10 magazine}}</ref> Wong's own showpiece, a [[Caonima]] (alpaca) sculpture, was one of the stars of the show.<ref name=henders/> Since then, Wong has become known for his eye-catching displays at public demonstrations drawing attention to Hong Kong's political situation.<ref name=artnet273789>{{cite web|last1=Zoe|first1=Li|title=Kacey Wong's Protest Art Goes on View in Hong Kong in the Wake of the Umbrella Movement|url=http://news.artnet.com/art-world/kacey-wongs-protest-art-goes-on-view-in-hong-kong-in-the-wake-of-the-umbrella-movement-273789|website=artnet.news|date=5 March 2015|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=apple18878618>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20140925/18878618|script-title=zh:黃國才：用藝術去改變世界|work=Apple Daily |date=25 September 2014|language=zh}}</ref>
Fond of quoting Ai, Wong believes that art and politics are indissociable, and that no art is completely without political connotation. Wong sees art as one of the organic elements in the mix of political movements, playing an indirect and auxiliary role.<ref name="arts-news.net"/><ref name=ecozine>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecozine.com/article/kacey-wong|title=Kacey Wong|author=Wong, Esther |date=8 May 2013|work=Ecozine}}</ref> He has variously participated in the annual [[Hong Kong 1 July marches|1 July protest marches]] riding in a pink armoured personnel carrier, walking around with a facsimile washing machine on his head, and guiding a 10-foot red robot he created.<ref name=20140309mingpao/><ref>"城市夢遊"， ''Next Magazine'', 13 September 2012 {{zh icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20130701/18318313|script-title=zh:藝術家製道具讓市民進擊 10呎「共人」諷吃人政權 |date=1 July 2013|work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref> For the march on 1 July 2014, Wong created the “Warning Squad", where he and several people dressed as police officers holding parody banners inspired by those increasingly seen used by police officers at protests. His signs included “Love the Party” – echoing the CPC slogan “Love the country, love the Party” (愛國愛黨) – “Fake Commie”; “Party-State” referring to the one-party state within China; “Reddening” referring to the gradual infiltration of the communist ethos into Hong Kong; “Land Grabbing” referring to the land acquisition for development in the Northeast New Territories.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2014/07/15/warning-squad-polices-repression-of-pro-democracy-protesters/|title=Protest art criticises police 'repression' of pro-democracy activists |work=Hong Kong Free Press}}</ref>
[[File:Kacey blind side.jpg|thumb|260px|Wong drawing portraits during the Umbrella Revolution]]Wong was highly active during the [[Umbrella Revolution]]: he held a contest for the best logo to elevate awareness and generate more concern for the demand for "real universal suffrage" for Hong Kong. Using social media as a "safe platform" for universal participation, he generated considerable awareness and received entries from all over the world.<ref name=artnet121249>{{cite web|url=http://news.artnet.com/art-world/artists-design-logos-for-hong-kongs-umbrella-revolution-121249|title=Best designs for the Hong Kong Umbrella Revolution|author= Li, Zoe|date=3 October 2014|work=artnet News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tom-silva/branding-a-revolution_b_6017088.html|title=Branding a Revolution|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref><ref name=bbc29407067>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-29407067|title=How the humble umbrella became a HK protest symbol|date=29 September 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=20140929SCMPchow>Chow, Vivienne (29 September 2014). [http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1603858/umbrella-revolution-designers-come-logos-occupy-central-protests "Umbrella Revolution: more designs on Hong Kong’s protest movement"]. ''South China Morning Post''</ref> Wong held sessions where he would draw a person's portrait in one minute without looking at the paper – the concept inspired by [[Nelson Mandela]]'s maxim "It always seems impossible until it's done". He also co-founded [[Umbrella Movement Art Preservation]], to make an inventory of works and their locations at protest sites, aiming to rescue key pieces before police clearances.<ref name=20141116bostonglobe>Sataline, Suzanne (16 November 2014). [https://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2014/11/16/will-hong-kong-protest-art-saved/K5i9zT8PyR4lcAU74Dcl8O/story.html "Will Hong Kong’s protest art be saved?"] ''Boston Globe''</ref><ref name=20141115NYTjoyce>Lau, Joyce (14 November 2014). [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/15/world/asia/rescuing-protest-artwork-from-hong-kongs-streets.html "Art Spawned by Protest; Now to Make It Live On"]. ''The New York Times''.</ref>
For his personal exhibition in March 2015 entitled "Resisting Against Absurdity", Wong reunited pieces he created for previous protest marches and added new works:<ref name=artnet273789/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1735273/hong-kong-artists-break-loose-confines-market-forces-amid-art-basel|title=Hong Kong artists break loose from confines of market forces amid Art Basel|date=11 March 2015|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref> in particular the ''Black Cop Candle'' – a set of wax statues of policemen in riot gear and raised batons. These symbolise the seven "black" (meaning corrupt) cops who beat up a protester and who were caught on film so doing during the 2014 protests; lighting the candles would melt them and transform them into light.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Artists-take-stock-of-the-Umbrella-Movement/37299 |title=Artists take stock of the Umbrella Movement |date=17 March 2015 |work=The Art Newspaper |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150320185212/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Artists-take-stock-of-the-Umbrella-Movement/37299 |archivedate=20 March 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Lifestyle/Entertainment/Arts/Frame-Up/2015/03/17/Art-and-politics-collide-at-Art-Basel-Hong-Kong/|title=Art and politics collide at Art Basel Hong Kong |date=17 March 2015 |work=The Star|location=Malaysia}}</ref>
[[File:Kidnap by Kacey Wong.jpg|thumb|260px|Wong protesting at booksellers' disappearances with red gallows bearing the Chinese characters for "abduction" as props]]At a march protesting at the [[Causeway Bay Books disappearances|disappearances of the staff of Causeway Bay Books in 2015]], Wong symbolically constructed a red gallows carrying the Chinese characters for "abduction" (綁架), bound himself with red rope and gagged himself with red duct tape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hkm.appledaily.com/detail.php?issue=20160110&guid=54630461&category_guid=7018882&category=instant|title=【曾為何韻詩設計太空船】本地藝術家黃國才親歷血紅綁架|work=Apple Daily |language=zh}}</ref>
=== Other roles === Wong co-founded Street Design Union to study and advance the role of artists and designers in the socio-political sphere.<ref name=ecozine/> Since 2001, he has taken his "Personal Skyscraper Workshops" to primary schools to encourage children to admire the architecture. He does this by having pupils create wearable architectural clothing with foam boards and paper.<ref name=muse/>
In 2016, the [[M+]] in Hong Kong commissioned Wong to create the "M+ Rover" – a mobile gallery for their schools outreach programme. The Rover was created out of a hollowed-out container in which was installed a wooden interior using disused pallets to create the feel of a whale.<ref>http://www.westkowloon.hk/en/whats-on/current-forthcoming/m-rover</ref>
== Personal == Wong is an avid fan of war-games – an activity he partakes in every week which he says helps with mental agility. He also enjoys diving.<ref name=muse/> Wong and his wife Margaret live with Ballball – a cat which had lost an eye in an accident. Wong chose to adopt him over other cats because he was unique.<ref name=2011raw/><ref name=artplus42>"黃國才", pp 16–19, ''Art Plus''. No. 41 {{zh icon}}</ref> Wong said: "Imagine you were to go to a pet shop and ask for a one-eyed cat... 'Sorry we don't do those' would be the response".<ref name=artplus42/> {{clear}}

{{italic}} [[File:Pablo_Picasso_-_La_Gommeuse.jpg|thumb|right|Pablo Picasso, ''La Gommeuse'', 1901, oil on canvas,31 7/8 by 21 1/4 in (81.3 by 54 cm)]] [[File:Pablo_Picasso_-_Caricature_of_Pere_Mañach.jpg|thumb|right|Caricature of Pere Mañach on the reverse]] [[File:Pedro Mañach.JPG|thumb|right|''Pere Mañach'', 1901, [[National Gallery of Art]]]] '''''La Gommeuse''''' {{IPA-fr|la ɡɔmøz|}} is a 1901 [[oil on canvas]] painting by the Spanish artist [[Pablo Picasso]]. It dates from his so-called [[Picasso's Blue Period | Blue period]] and is noted for its caricature of Picasso's friend Pere Mañach painted on the reverse.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Mark|title=Blue period Picasso – with a little secret – goes under the hammer|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/oct/09/picasso-la-gommeuse-blue-period-auction|publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Singh|first1=Anita|title=The US billionaire who got two Picassos for the price of one|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/artsales/11922971/The-US-billionaire-who-got-two-Picassos-for-the-price-of-one.html|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref> It was offered for sale ''ex'' the [[Bill Koch (businessman) | William I. Koch]] collection at a [[Sotheby's]], New York, auction on 5 November 2015.<ref name= "Sotheby's">{{cite web|title=''La Gommeuse''|url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2015/impressionist-modern-art-evening-sale-n09415/lot.26.html|publisher=[[Sotheby's]]}}</ref> The painting realized $67.5 million at the sale, a record for a Blue period Picasso and placing the painting among the [[List_of_most_expensive_paintings#List_of_highest_prices_paid | most expensive ever sold]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pogrebin|first1=Robin|title=Warmer Response at Sotheby’s 2nd Night of Auctions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/06/arts/design/warmer-response-at-sothebys-2nd-night-of-auctions.html|publisher=[[New York Times]]}}</ref>
''Gommeuse'' was sexually charged slang of the time for café-concert singers and their songs.<ref name= "Sotheby's"/>
== Background ==
The painting was executed in the second half of 1901 following Picasso's successful exhibition at the [[Vollard]] gallery that June. This was at the start of his [[Picasso's Blue Period | Blue period]] of 1901 to 1904, thought to have been occasioned by the suicide of his friend [[Carlos Casagemas]] earlier in the year, a time when his paintings were somewhat melancholic and characterized by somber monochromatic tones in blue and green.<ref name= "Sotheby's"/>
The caricature of Picasso's friend Pere Mañach on the reverse is inscribed "Recuerdo a Mañach en el día de su santo", demonstrating the painting was intended as a gift for Mañach on his Saint's Day (29 June). Mañach was a Catalan anarchist who shared Picasso's studio flat in the [[Boulevard de Clichy]]. He worked as a talent scout for art dealers and was responsible for organising Picasso's successful 1901 Vollard show. A portrait of Mañach, now in the [[National Gallery of Art]], Washington, was a feature of the show.<ref name= "Sotheby's"/>
==See also== * [[List of most expensive paintings]]
== Provenance ==
* Ambroise Vollard, Paris * Demotte Gallery, New York (1931) * Josef von Sternberg, Hollywood (acquired from the above before 1935 and sold: Parke Bernet Galleries, New York, November 22, 1949, lot 89) * Perls Gallery, New York (acquired at the above sale) * Jacques Sarlie, New York (sold: Sotheby’s, London, October 12, 1960, lot 5) * Galerie Alex Maguy, Paris (acquired at the above sale) * William I. Koch (sale: Sotheby’s, London, December 4, 1984, lot 23 ) * Private collection (sale: Sotheby's, New York, November 5, 2015, lot 26) <ref name= "Sotheby's"/>

{{Orphan|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{expand list|date=July 2012}} The following is a '''list of film- and television-related occupations'''. ==Animation== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Title(s) !Area !Description |- |Animator |Film |Artist who creates multiple images that give an illusion of movement called animation when displayed in rapid sequence; the images are called frames and [[key frame]]s. Animators can work in a variety of fields including film, television, video games, and the internet. |- |[[Cartoonist]] |TV |Specializes in drawing [[cartoon]]s. This work is usually humorous, mainly created for entertainment, political commentary or advertising. |- |[[Tweening|Tweener]] |Film and TV |Makes drawings between the "key poses" drawn by the animator, and also re-draw any sketches that are too roughly made to be used as such. |- |} ==Film-specific== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Title(s) !Description |- |[[Casting director]] |Chooses the actors for the characters of the film. This usually involves inviting potential actors to read an excerpt from the script for an [[audition]]. |- |[[Cinematographer]] |Chief over the camera and lighting [[film crew|crew]]s working on a film, responsible for achieving artistic and technical decisions related to the image. |- |Executive producer |An executive producer (EP) is a producer who is not involved in the technical aspects of the filmmaking process, but has played a crucial financial or creative role in ensuring that the project goes into production. There may be several Executive producers on a film who may take the lead role in a number of areas, such as development, financing or production. Executive producers must be excellent negotiators. They need a keen business sense, and an intimate knowledge of all aspects of film production, financing, marketing and distribution. Executive producers are responsible for the overall quality control of productions. On some productions the executive producer role may be combined with other roles, so that as well as raising the finance they may also be responsible for managing the budget during production. Executive producers must be able to identify commercial, marketable projects. Executive producers have overall responsibility for the successful financing and marketing of these projects. During production, executive producers may be involved in some aspects of scripting, casting, and crewing. Executive producers often work on a number of projects simultaneously. They are experienced industry practitioners, who have usually worked previously for a number of years in any one of a variety of roles, such as producer, writer, director or script editor. |- |Film director |The film director directs the actors and [[film crew]] in filmmaking.[http://dictionary.cambridge.org/define.asp?key=101891anddict=CALD Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary] They control a film's artistic and dramatic aspects, while guiding the [[technical crew]] and actors. The director is involved throughout all phases of the film. They are usually experienced in a variety of areas in film such as writing, editing, acting etc. |- |Film producer |A film producer creates the conditions for [[Film making|making movies]]. The producer initiates, coordinates, supervises, and controls matters such as raising funding, hiring key personnel, and arranging for distributors. The producer is involved throughout ''all'' phases of the film making process from development to completion of a project. |- |[[Production manager]] |The production manager supervises the physical aspects of the production (not the creative aspects) including personnel, technology, budget, and scheduling. It is the production manager's responsibility to make sure the filming stays on schedule and within its budget. The PM also helps manage the day-to-day budget by managing operating costs such as salaries, production costs, and everyday equipment rental costs. The PM often works under the supervision of a line producer and directly supervises the production coordinator. |- |Screenwriter |The screenwriter, or scriptwriter, may pitch a finished script to potential producers and directors or may write a script under contract to a producer. A writer may be involved, to varied degrees, with creative aspects of production. |- |[[Stunt coordinator]] |Where the film requires a [[stunt]], and involves the use of [[stunt performer]]s, the stunt coordinator will arrange the casting and performance of the stunt, working closely with the director. |- |} ==Other== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Title(s) !Area !Description |- |nowrap|Actor |Film and TV |person who acts in a dramatic or comic production and who works in film, television, theatre, or [[radio programming|radio]] in that capacity. {{cite web|url=http://www.prospects.ac.uk/cms/ShowPage/Home_page/Explore_types_of_jobs/Types_of_Job/p!eipaL?state=showoccandpageno=1andidno=465|title=actor: Job description and activities|publisher=Prospects UK|accessdate=2009-02-12|last=|first=}} |- |[[Costume designer]] |Film and TV |designs costumes for a film or stage production. |- |[[Lighting technician]] |Film and TV | |- |[[Make-up artist]] |Film and TV | |- |nowrap|[[News presenter]]{{*}}Reporter
[[Newscaster]]{{*}}[[Anchorman]] |Film and TV |[[Television presenter|presents]] news during a [[news program]] in the format of a television show, on the radio or the Internet. News presenters can work in a television studio and from [[remote broadcast]]s in the field especially [[weather forecaster]]s. |- |Screenwriter | | |- |[[Video editor]] | | |- |Voice actor |Film and TV | |- |[[Weather forecasting|Weatherman/woman]] |TV | |- |} ==See also== *[[Lists of occupations]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Lists of occupations|Film]] [[Category:Film industry|*]] [[Category:Lists of media|film and television occupations]]

{{For|the Michelangelo sculpture|Medici Madonna}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Rogier van der Weyden 021.jpg | image_size= 300px | title=Medici Madonna | artist=[[Rogier van der Weyden]] | year=c. 1460–1464 | type=[[Oil painting|Oil]] on panel | height_metric=61.7 | width_metric=46.1 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=[[Städel]], Frankfurt }} The '''''Medici Madonna''''' is an [[panel painting|oil-on-panel]] painting by the [[early Netherlandish painting|Netherlandish]] artist [[Rogier van der Weyden]], dating from around 1460–1464 and housed in the [[Städel]], [[Frankfurt]], Germany.
The work is known to have been commissioned by the [[Medici]] family in [[Florence]], as testified by the Florentine coat of arms with a red lily at the center of the lower step. The work has been variously dated from 1450–1451, when the artist travelled to Rome visiting several Italian courts, or from 1460–1464, the same years of the ''[[Lamentation of Christ (Rogier van der Weyden)|Lamentation of Christ]]'', inspired by [[Beato Angelico]] and now at the [[Uffizi]].
==Description== Above a gold background, van der Weyden painted a baldachin lined with precious [[damask]] cloth, under which are the [[Virgin with Child]], St. Peter, St. John the Baptist (patron saint of Florence), St. Cosmas (a protector of the House of Medici), and St. Damian. [[Saints Cosmas and Damian|Cosmas]] is portrayed while putting a coin in a handbag hanging from his belt, a reference of his legend, according to which he had accepted a small sum for a medical performance, causing rage in his brother Damian.
In the foreground is a still life with the artist's typical attention to natural details. In the centre is a gilt metallic [[amphora]], in which are several lilies: the white ones symbolize the Virgin's purity, while the red ones are another reference to Florence.
==Sources== *{{cite book|last= Campbell|first=Lorne |year=2004|title=Van der Weyden|location=London|publisher=Chaucer Press|isbn=1-904449-24-7 }} * [https://sammlung.staedelmuseum.de/de/werk/medici-madonna Städel: Mix technique]
{{Rogier van der Weyden}}

{{For|the related function in opera|Prompter (opera)}} <!---All citations are in MLA author-date system -- see talk page Manual of Style guidelines for details.---> {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use British English|date=September 2016}} [[File:Apuntador (souffleur) del siglo XVIII.jpg|thumb|An 18th-century prompter at work.]] [[File:Harvard Theatre Collection - TS Promptbooks Sh 154.75, Henry Irving 1874.jpg|thumb|right|The prompt book from an 1874 staging of ''[[Hamlet]]'' by English actor and manager [[Henry Irving]] (1838-1905), in which he experimented with using limelight (burning calcium oxide) to represent the [[Ghost (Hamlet)|ghost of Hamlet’s father]].]] The '''prompter''' (sometimes '''prompt''') in a [[Theater (building)|theatre]] is a person who prompts or cues [[actor]]s when they forget their lines or neglect to move on the [[stage (theatre)|stage]] to where they are supposed to be situated.<ref>Kennedy (2010), Pavis (1998, 289), and Taylor (1993, 253—254).</ref>
Nowadays, many of the earlier duties of the prompter are undertaken by the [[Stage management|stage manager]], who will have a copy of the script called the '''prompt book'''.<ref name=ken>Kennedy (2010).</ref> This is the most definitive version of the script for any one performance, and will contain details of all [[cue (theatrical)|cues]], with their precise timings with respect to the action on stage. <ref name=hart>Hartnoll and Found (1996).</ref> This allows the prompt to direct [[Lighting design|lighting]], [[Sound design|sound]], [[fly system|flying]] effects and scene changes during a show. The prompt book also often contains [[Blocking (stage)|blocking]] notes, so that the prompt is always aware of the intended positions and movements of all the actors on stage at any given time.
In some [[professional]] and high-quality [[community theatre]] productions, the prompt is never used during a [[performance]] to instruct actors if they forget a line or movement, only during a [[rehearsal]]. If prompting is absolutely necessary, it is done very quietly by another actor on-stage.
The prompt is located on the stage, in the [[prompt corner]] or "prompt side".<ref name=ken/>
In Elizabethan theatre the function of prompting was filled by the Book-Holder, who was also in charge of [[stage prop|prop]]s and calls.<ref name=hart/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== {{refbegin}} * Hartnoll, Phyllis and Peter Found, eds. 1996. ''The Concise Oxford Companion to the Theatre.'' Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-282574-7}}. * Kennedy, Dennis, ed. 2010. ''The Oxford Companion to Theatre and Performance.'' Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-957419-3}}. * [[Patrice Pavis|Pavis, Patrice]]. 1998. ''Dictionary of the Theatre: Terms, Concepts, and Analysis''. Trans. Christine Shantz. Toronto and Buffalo: University of Toronto Press. {{ISBN|0-802-08163-0}}. * [[John Russell Taylor|Taylor, John Russell]]. 1993. ''The Penguin Dictionary of the Theatre.'' 3rd ed. London: Penguin. {{ISBN|0-140-51287-X}}. {{refend}}

{{other uses}} {{Wiktionary|protagonist}} [[Image:Hamlet William Morris Hunt.jpeg|thumb|200px|[[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Hamlet]], Prince of Denmark.'' William Morris Hunt, oil on canvas, circa 1864]] A '''protagonist''' ({{ety|grc|''πρωταγωνιστής'' (protagonistes)|one who plays the first part, chief actor}}) <ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dprwtagwnisth%2Fs πρωταγωνιστής], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus Digital Library.</ref><ref>[http://www.dictionary.com/browse/protagonist "protagonist"]. [[Dictionary.com]], [[Random House]]. Retrieved November 17, 2017.</ref> is the leading character of a story.
The protagonist is at the center of the story, makes the key decisions, and experiences the consequences of those decisions. The protagonist is the primary agent propelling the story forward, and is often the character who faces the most significant obstacles. If a story contains a [[subplot]], or is a narrative made up of several stories, then each subplot may have its own protagonist.<ref>Duncan, Stephen. ''A Guide to Screenwriting Success: Writing for Film and Television''. Rowman & Littlefield (2006) {{ISBN|9780742553019}}</ref>
The protagonist is the character whose fate is most closely followed by the reader or audience, and who is opposed by the [[antagonist]]. The antagonist will provide obstacles and complications and create conflicts that test the protagonist, thus revealing the strengths and weaknesses of the protagonist's character.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=protagonist&searchmode=none|title=protagonist - Search Online Etymology Dictionary|website=www.etymonline.com}}</ref>
==Ancient Greece== The earliest known examples of a protagonist are found in [[Ancient Greece]]. At first, dramatic performances involved merely dancing and recitation by the chorus. Then in ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]'', [[Aristotle]] describes how a poet named [[Thespis]] introduced the idea of one actor stepping out and engage in a dialogue with the chorus. This was the invention of tragedy, and occurred about 536 B.C.<ref>Müller, K.O. ''History of the literature of Ancient Greece''. [Library of Useful Knowledge.] Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge. London (1840) page 306</ref> Then the poet [[Aeschylus]], in his plays, introduced a second actor, inventing the idea of dialogue between two characters. [[Sophocles]] then wrote plays that included a third actor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/art/protagonist|title=Protagonist - literature|publisher=}}</ref><ref>Aristotle. ''Poetics''. Oxford University Press (January 20, 2013) {{ISBN|978-0199608362}}</ref><ref>[[William Packard (author)|Packard, William]]. ''The Art of the Playwright''. Thunder’s Mouth Press. 1997 {{ISBN|1-56025-117-4}}</ref><ref>Storey, Ian. Allan, Arlene. ''A Guide to Ancient Greek Drama''. John Wiley & Sons (2008) {{ISBN|9781405137638}}. page 84</ref>
A description of the protagonist's origin cited that during the early period of Greek drama, the protagonist served as the author, the director, and the actor and that these roles were only separated and allocated to different individuals later.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=0jhjDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT235&dq=protagonist+definition+classical+greece&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDk7mB5PPeAhUmrlQKHXCxDT4Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=protagonist%20definition%20classical%20greece&f=false|title=Moreno's Personality Theory and its Relationship to Psychodrama: A Philosophical, Developmental and Therapeutic Perspective|last=Telias|first=Rozei|date=2018-07-06|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781351021081|language=en}}</ref> There is also a claim that the poet did not assign or create the protagonist as well as other terms for actors such as ''deuteragonist'' and ''tritagonist'' primarily because he only gave actors their appropriate part.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=lgpaDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT513&dq=protagonist+protagonistes+classical+greece&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjL0faS5PPeAhXT0J8KHbm9DSkQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=protagonist%20protagonistes%20classical%20greece&f=false|title=History of the Literature of Ancient Greece|last=Bart|first=M. P.|date=2018-03-22|publisher=Charles River Editors|isbn=9781632956316|language=en}}</ref> However, these actors were assigned their specific areas at the stage with the protagonist always entering from the middle door or that the dwelling of the ''[[deuteragonist]]'' (second most important character) should be on the right hand, and the ''[[tritagonist]]'' (third most important character), the left.<ref name=":0" />
In Ancient Greece, the protagonist is distinguished from the term "hero", which was used to refer to a human who became a semi-divine being. in the narrative.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Guide to Ancient Greek Drama|last=Storey|first=Ian|last2=Allan|first2=Arlene|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|year=2008|isbn=1405102144|location=Malden, MA|pages=84}}</ref>
==Examples==
[[Euripides]]' play ''[[Hippolytus (play)|Hippolytus]]'' may be considered to have two protagonists. Phaedra is the protagonist of the first half, who dies partway through the play. Her stepson, the titular Hippolytus, assumes the dominant role in the second half of the play.<ref>Euripides. ''Hippolytos''. Oxford University Press (October 29, 1992) {{ISBN|978-0195072907}}</ref>
In [[Ibsen]]’s play ''[[The Master Builder]]'', the protagonist is the architect Halvard Solness. The young woman, Hilda Wangel, whose actions lead to the death of Solness, is the antagonist.<ref>Ibsen, Henrik. Meyer, Michael Leverson. editor. ''Ibsen Plays: 1: Ghosts; The Wild Duck; The Master Builder''. Dramatists Play Service Inc. (1980) {{ISBN|9780413463302}}. page 241</ref>
In Shakespeare’s play ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', Romeo is the protagonist. He is actively in pursuit of his relationship with Juliet, and the audience is invested in that story. Tybalt, as an antagonist, opposes Romeo and attempts to thwart the relationship.<ref>Shakespeare, William. ''Romeo and Juliet''. Bloomsbury Arden Shakespeare; Third edition (July 15, 2012) {{ISBN|9781903436912}}</ref>
In Shakespeare’s play ''[[Hamlet]]'', Prince Hamlet, who seeks revenge for the murder of his father, is the protagonist. The antagonist would be the character who most opposes Hamlet, Claudius (though, in many ways, Hamlet is his own antagonist).<ref>Shakespeare, William. ''Hamlet''. Simon & Schuster (July 1, 1992) {{ISBN|978-0743477123}}</ref>
Sometimes, a work will have a [[false protagonist]], who may seem to be the protagonist, but then may disappear unexpectedly. The character Marion in [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s film ''[[Psycho (1960 film)|Psycho]]'' (1960) is an example.<ref>Kolker, Robert Phillip. ''Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho: A Casebook''. Oxford University Press (2004) {{ISBN|9780195169195}}</ref>
A novel that contains a number of narratives may have a number of protagonists. [[Alexander Solzhenitsyn]]'s ''[[The First Circle]]'', for example, depicts a variety of characters imprisoned and living in a [[gulag]] camp.<ref>''The Solzhenitsyn Reader: New and Essential Writings, 1947–2005: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn'', Edward E. Ericson, Jr., Daniel J. Mahoney.</ref> [[Leo Tolstoy]]'s ''[[War and Peace]]'', depicts fifteen major characters involved in or affected by a war.<ref>Moser, Charles. 1992. ''Encyclopedia of Russian Literature''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 298–300.</ref>
''[[Little Women]]'' boasts a cast of over five diverse females struggling with the inevitability of the crossing between childhood and womenhood.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/14932247|title=A hunger for home : Louisa May Alcott's place in American culture|last=Sarah.|first=Elbert,|date=1987|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=0813511992|location=New Brunswick|oclc=14932247}}</ref>
In [[Charlotte Brontë]]'s novel ''[[Jane Eyre]]'', Jane's spiritual and emotional growth captivate the social criticism of its day, exploring heavy subjects such as [[classism]], [[Human sexuality|sexuality]], [[religion]], and [[proto-feminism]] during the early 1800s.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Charlotte Brontë's Novels: The Accents of Persuasion|last=Martin|first=Robert B|publisher=Norton|year=1996|isbn=|location=NY|pages=}}</ref>
In [[Peter and Wendy]], ''[[Wendy Darling]]'' is the protagonist.
In some cases, the protagonist is not a human: in [[Richard Adams]]' novel ''[[Watership Down]],'' a group of [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphised]] rabbits, led by the protagonist Hazel, escape their warren after seeing a vision of its destruction, starting a perilous journey to find a new home.<ref>Adams, Richard, 1920-2016. Watership Down. London :Rex Collings Ltd, 1972. Print.</ref>

{{Infobox short story | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Replacements | title_orig = | translator = | author = [[Lisa Tuttle]] | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | published_in = | publication_type = | publisher = | media_type = Print | pub_date = 1992 | english_pub_date = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''"Replacements"''' is a [[short story]] by American writer [[Lisa Tuttle]]. It concern a husband's surfacing insecurities as his wife's independence strengthens when she claims a bloodsucking pet for her very own.
Tuttle declared in an interview with M. M. Hall from ''Fantastic Metropolis'': "My first post-natal story to deal with in any way with motherhood was “Replacements”, written when my daughter was only seven months old. Make of that what you will…".<ref name="fantastic">[http://www.fantasticmetropolis.com/i/tuttle/full/ The Mysterious Q&A with Lisa Tuttle with M.M. hall]</ref>
"Replacements" has been widely reprinted since being first published in 1992, both in Tuttle's own short story collections and various writers anthologies. It was also included on various "best of" anthologies in the year.
== Summary == As Stuart commences his walk to work, he notices an animal "about the size of a cat, naked looking, with leathery, hairless skin and thin, spiky limbs that seemed too frail to support the bulbous, ill-proportioned body." <ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0452274893/ ''American Gothic Tales'': edited with introduction by Joyce Carol Oates, New York: Plume, 1996]</ref> Disgusted and horrified by the appearance of this animal, he crushes it with his foot. Immediately, he is remorseful and his first instinct is to call his wife Jenny. Since he is not sure what her reaction will be, he waits to call her at the normal time in the afternoon. She is not able to take his call and does not return the call either. Stuart calls again, only to find that she has left work early. This, being unlike her, worries Stuart and he returns home as soon as possible.
Once home, he finds that Jenny brought one of the "creatures" with her. Stuart shows strong dislike towards the creature and wants Jenny to get rid of it. The two argue about what to do with Jenny's new "pet" but never come to a resolution. The creature begins taking up more of Jenny's time and attention. She also does abnormal activities with the creature (letting it drink blood from her). As this progresses, Stuart is regarded less and less and becomes very distanced from Jenny. Eventually, Jenny says that she is going to keep it whether Stuart likes it or not. Stuart then decides that he cannot live with the creature and the woman Jenny has become, and he moves out.
He begins to notice these creatures more and more. The women at work, women on the streets - every woman he sees seems to have one of these creatures. One evening while on his way home from work, he notices a woman sitting opposite with a gold chain that brings back memories. After leaving the train at the same stop as the woman, he strives to come up with something to say, but he sees the chain linked to one of the "pets" he despises and immediately lets her walk away. He absentmindedly walks to his old house where he sees the creature longing to be outside and he longing to be in.
==Adaptations== The story was adapted for the 12th episode of ''[[The Hunger (TV series)|The Hunger]]'' season 2, also titled "Replacements" (28 November 1999).

{{Infobox |above=Socialist realism in Poland |image1=[[File:Nowahuta.jpg|256px|alt=Nowa Huta]] |caption1=Socrealist centre of [[Nowa Huta]] district of [[Kraków]] (Aleja Róż Plaza, 2003) }} {{Culture of Poland}} '''Socialist realism in Poland''' ({{lang-pl|'''socrealizm'''}}) was a social, political, and esthetic doctrine enforced by the pro-Soviet communist government in the process of [[Stalinization]] of the postwar [[People's Republic of Poland]]. The official policy was introduced in 1949 by a decree of the [[Polish United Workers' Party]] minister (later, Minister of Culture and Art) [[Włodzimierz Sokorski]]. As in all Soviet-dominated [[Eastern Bloc]] countries, [[Socialist realism]] became the main instrument [[History of Poland (1945–1989)|of political control]] in the building of [[totalitarianism]] in Poland. However, the trend has never become truly dominant. Following [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]]'s death on March 5, 1953, and the subsequent [[De-Stalinization]] of all [[People's Republic]]s, Polish artists, writers and architects started abandoning it around 1955. The De-Stalinization process peaked during the [[Polish October]].
==History== [[File:KulturpalastWarschau.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Palace of Culture and Science in [[Warsaw]] built using Soviet-drawn [[blueprint]]s in 1952–1955]] The policy was enforced in Poland between 1949 and 1956 amidst the wave of gross human rights abuses committed by [[Ministry of Public Security (Poland)|the state security forces]]. It involved all domains of cultural politics including visual, music and literary arts, though its most spectacular achievements were made in the [[Culture of Poland#Architecture|field of architecture]]. The objectives of this new trend were explained in a 1949 resolution of the National Council of Party Architects. Architecture was declared a key weapon in the creation of a new [[social order]]. It was intended to help spread the communist ideology by influencing citizens' consciousness as well as their outlook on life.
During this massive undertaking, a crucial role fell to designers perceived not as merely architects creating streets and edifices, but rather as "[[engineers of the human soul]]". The idea extended beyond aesthetics and into principles of [[urban design]] meant to express grandiose expectations and arouse [[Propaganda of success|feelings of stability]] and [[Propaganda in the Polish People's Republic|political power monopoly]] in [[Stalinist Poland]].
==Local characteristics== [[File:Ministry of Agriculture Warsaw.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Ministry of Agriculture, Warsaw, built 1953–1956]] Since the [[Renaissance in Poland#Polish Renaissance architecture|style of the Renaissance]] was generally regarded as the most revered in old Polish architecture, it was to become Poland's socialist national format. However, in the course of incorporating these principles into new ideology, major changes were also introduced. One of these was to more closely reflect [[Stalinist architecture|Soviet architecture]], which resulted in the majority of new buildings blending into one another. The all-encompassing Stalinist vision propagated by the Soviet Union was best exemplified by the new [[Palace of Culture and Science, Warsaw|Joseph Stalin Palace of Culture and Science]] (''Pałac Kultury i Nauki imienia Józefa Stalina'') constructed in [[Warsaw]] between 1952 and 1955.<ref name="Palace-1">{{cite web|url=http://www.hum.au.dk/ckulturf/pages/publications/mz/architect.htm |title=The Height of (Architectural) Seduction: Reading the "Changes" through Stalin's Palace in Warsaw, Poland |author=Magdalena J. Zaborowska |accessdate=2008-04-18 |publisher=Centre for Cultural Research, University of Aarhus }}</ref> Its design was based on [[Seven Sisters (Moscow)|similar skyscrapers built in the USSR]] at that time. The 3,500 builders were brought in directly from the Soviet Union with their own blueprints, and housed in a suburban shantytown.<ref name="Palace-2" >{{cite web|url=http://www.bestufs.net/download/conferences/Warsaw_May07/BESTUFS_Warsaw_May07_Conference_Leaflet.pdf |publisher=Best Urban Freight Solutions |title=Warsaw Palace of Culture and Science |date=May 24, 2007 |format=pdf }}</ref>
The monumental form disseminated by the Communist Government reached its apogee with the construction of an entire new town near [[Kraków]] along with a [[steel mill]] soon to become the biggest in Poland. [[Nowa Huta]] was [[central planning|centrally planned]] as a major new centre of heavy industry, against substantial resistance from middle-class Cracovians. Its Main Square (''Plac Centralny'') was surrounded by huge blocks of flats populated by a new class of industrial workers employed at the [[Lenin]] Steelworks. Notably, the [[socrealism|socrealist]] centre of Nowa Huta is currently considered a monument of architecture. Other prominent examples of urban design included Marszałkowska Housing Estate (MDM) in Warsaw, Kościuszkowska Housing Estate (KDM) in [[Wrocław]], Main Station [[Gdynia Główna]], a housing estate in [[Kowary]], and the Palace of [[Upper Silesian Coal Basin|Coal-Basin]] Culture in [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]].
==Painting and sculpture== [[File:Wojciech-Weiss-Manifest(1950-painting).jpg|thumb|left|upright|"Manifesto" by [[Wojciech Weiss]], 1950]] Socialist [[realism (arts)|realism]] in [[Culture of Poland#Art|Polish art]] was confined to portraits of party leaders and various depictions of muscular labourers and battle scenes, with special attention paid to popular taste. Formally inspired by [[Neoclassicism]] as well as the local folk art, socrealism served strictly political and [[Propaganda in the Soviet Union|pro-Soviet propaganda]] purposes; however, its most notable artists, such as [[Wojciech Weiss]] and [[Włodzimierz Zakrzewski]] were educated before Stalinism and inadvertently adhered to traditional Western techniques and technologies. Some of the most blatantly socrealist paintings were: "Pass-on the brick" (''Podaj cegłę'') [http://www.malarze.com/obraz.php?id=683&l=pl pictured here], by [[Aleksander Kobzdej]], and "Thank you tractor operator" (''Podziękowanie traktorzyście'') [https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/-4qAnzEopvGc/R8HonUO9tGI/AAAAAAAAIJM/zjB3p8ty0Q0/w799-h599-no/P2230167.JPG pictured here], as well as "Comrade [[Bierut]] among labourers" (''Towarzysz Bierut wśród robotników'') by Helena and Juliusz Krajewski. [[File:Socrealizm.jpeg|thumb|upright|Socialist-Realist [[allegory|allegories]] surrounding the [[Palace of Culture and Science in Warsaw]]]]
In sculpture, there was a trend toward stone-carved allegories elevating the common worker, used mainly for architectural purposes, such as those surrounding the Palace of Culture and Science in Warsaw, including mostly plaster busts of communist [[apparatchik]]s. The collection of Polish socrealist sculpture is exhibited at Kozłówka Palace near [[Lubartów]].
==Film and music== {{see also|Socialist realism in Polish literature}} While the socialist realism doctrine in [[Cinema of the Soviet Union|Soviet cinema]] originated around the time of the [[Bolshevik Revolution]] ([[Sergei Eisenstein|Eisenstein]], [[Alexander Dovzhenko|Dovzhenko]], [[Vsevolod Pudovkin|Pudovkin]]) and reached its peak in the 1930s, it did not have sufficient time to develop in postwar Poland. Therefore, the cult of the communist party remained alien to the local film industry. Among the more creative [[Cinema of Poland|Polish films]] loosely adhering to principles of socialist realism were ''Celuloza'' by [[Jerzy Kawalerowicz]], ''Pokolenie'' by [[Andrzej Wajda]] and ''Piątka z ulicy Barskiej'' by [[Aleksander Ford]]. The ideological stereotype gave birth to some inferior productions as well, such as ''Uczta Baltazara'' by Jerzy Zarzycki and Jerzy Passendorfer.
In [[Culture of Poland#Music|music]], the trend was limited to art song, film soundtrack, and pop-song based on local [[traditional music|folk tradition]]. Communist ideals were glorified in lyrics. Among the prominent composers were [[Jan Maklakiewicz]]: "Śląsk pracuje i śpiewa" (''Silesia Works and Sings''), Alfred Gradstein: "Na prawo most, na lewo most" (''A Bridge on the Right, and a Bridge on the Left''), and [[Andrzej Panufnik]]: "Symfonia Pokoju" (''The Symphony to Peace''). Widely promoted popular songs included "O Nowej to Hucie piosenka" (''This Song is about Nowa Huta'') [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JWCAsbEgZzo&feature=related featured here with the video]. The song is still well remembered by most Polish people of the older generation.
Following Stalin's death, and especially from 1953 on, critical opinions were heard with increasing frequency. Finally, as part of the [[Polish October|Gomułka political thaw]] from within the [[Polish United Workers' Party]], the entire doctrine was officially given up in 1956.<ref>Kimball King (2007), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=94LDaZ3efUYC&lpg=PA232&vq=thaw&dq=%22Leon%20Kruczkowski%22&lr&as_brr=3&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q=thaw&f=false Western Drama Through the Ages]'' Greenwood Publishing Group, p. 232.</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Real socialism]]'' concept of the [[Leonid Brezhnev|Brezhnev]] era
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * [http://free.of.pl/p/prl/pdstr/321.htm Socrealism - history, theory, list of publications, references and legal documents.] {{pl icon}} * Paweł Chmielewski, [http://www.pawech2.republika.pl/ros/awa/soc/s1.htm Socrealist art, architecture and literature] in the [[People's Republic of Poland]] {{pl icon}} * [http://1917.pl/index.php?option=com_content&task=section&id=14&Itemid=47 Ideological literary front of socrealism:] [[Władysław Broniewski|Broniewski]], [[Vladimir Mayakovsky|Mayakovsky]], [[Boris Pasternak|Pasternak]]. * {{cite web|title=Włodzimierz Zakrzewski, poster works|work=The Art of Poster|url=http://www.theartofposter.com/search2.asp?author=Zakrzewski+Wlodzimierz&title=&years=&category=all&country=all&print=all&director=&titleo=&actor=&countryp=all&authorp=&id=&Submit=++Search++}} * {{cite web|title=Some Like It Red - Polish Political Posters 1944–1989|first=Piotr|last=Dabrowski|url=http://www.theartofposter.com/RED/Red.htm}} * [http://www.usc.edu/dept/polish_music/composer/maklakiewicz.html Polish Music Center, University of Southern California: Jan Maklakiewicz, biography.] See also: [http://www.usc.edu/dept/polish_music/composer/composer.html Polish composers.]
==External links== {{Commons category|Socialist realism}} * [http://www.marxists.org/subject/art/visual_arts/painting/exhibits/socialist-realism.htm Socialist Realism page] at Marxists.org * [http://www.pkin.pl Palace of Culture and Science, Warsaw] * [http://www.palac.art.pl/ Palace of Coal-Basin Culture] in [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]] * [http://www.wojciechweiss.pl Wojciech Weiss Muzeum Foundation] * [http://culture.pl/en/article/top-10-socialist-realist-architectural-sculptures-in-warsaw Top 10 Socialist Realist Architectural Sculptures in Warsaw]

{{Infobox organization | logo = Society_of_American_Magicians_logo.png | formation = {{Start date and age|1902|05|10}} | leader_title = National President | leader_name = Ron Ishimaru | main_organ = ''M-U-M'' | slogan = Magic-Unity-Might | founding_location = [[New York City]] | website = {{URL|http://www.magicsam.com}} | membership = 5,000 }}[[File:Society of American Magicians Fourteenth Annual Dinner.png|thumb|S.A.M Fourteenth Annual Dinner, 1918]] The '''Society of American Magicians''' (S.A.M.) is the oldest fraternal [[Magic (illusion)|magic]] organization in the world. Its purpose is "to advance, elevate, and preserve magic as a performing art, to promote harmonious fellowship throughout the world of magic, and to maintain and improve ethical standards in the field of magic."<ref name="AboutSAM">{{cite news | url=http://www.magicsam.com/about.asp | title=About the Society of American Magicians | publisher=Society of American Magicians | year=2007 | first= | last= | accessdate=2007-06-05 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617225647/http://www.magicsam.com/about.asp | archivedate=2007-06-17 | df= }}</ref> To promote these endeavors the S.A.M. presents awards and fellowships in recognition of outstanding achievement in the Art of Magic.
Membership in the S.A.M. is open to professional magicians, amateur magicians, youth magicians, magic collectors, magic historians, magic inventors, magic manufacturers and magic dealers. Over 30,000 people worldwide have been members,<ref name="AboutSAM" /> and currently the S.A.M. has 5,000 members worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rodriguez|first1=Manon|title=National Administrator's Report|url=http://www.magicsam.org|website=Society of American Magicians|accessdate=28 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010812222139/http://www.magicsam.org/|archivedate=12 August 2001|df=}}</ref> The current National President of the S.A.M. is Ron Ishimaru.
==History== [[File:Houdini custom.jpg|alt=A close-up of Houdini staring to the camera|thumb|The Society grew under Harry Houdini's leadership—he is pictured here in 1920 in the middle of his tenure]] Founded on May 10, 1902 in the back room of [[Martinka]]'s magic shop in New York, the Society expanded under the leadership of [[Harry Houdini]] during his term as National President from 1917–1926. Houdini sought to create a large, unified national network of professional and amateur magicians. Wherever he traveled, Houdini would give a lengthy formal address to the local magic club, making speeches, and usually threw a banquet for the members at his own expense.
For most of 1916, while on his vaudeville tour, Houdini, at his own expense, had been recruiting local magic clubs to join the SAM in an effort to revitalize what he felt was a weak organization. Houdini persuaded groups in Buffalo, Detroit, Pittsburgh, and Kansas City to join. As had happened in London, Houdini persuaded magicians to join. The Buffalo club joined as the first branch, (later assembly) of the Society. Chicago Assembly No. 3 was, as the name implies, the third regional club to be established by the S.A.M., whose assemblies now number in the hundreds. In 1917, he signed Assembly Number Three's charter, and that charter and this club continue to provide Chicago magicians with a connection to each other and to their past. Houdini dined with, addressed, and got pledges from similar clubs in Detroit, Rochester, Pittsburgh, Kansas City, Cincinnati and elsewhere. This was the biggest movement ever in the history of magic. In places where no clubs existed, he rounded up individual magicians, introduced them to each other, and urged them into the fold. By the end of 1916, magicians' clubs in San Francisco and other cities that Houdini had not visited were offering to become assemblies. He had created the richest and longest surviving organization of magicians in the world.
The SAM now embraces over 5,000 members and almost 300 assemblies worldwide. In July, 1926, Houdini was elected for the ninth successive time President of the Society of American Magicians. Every other president has only served for one year. He also was President of the Magicians' Club of London.<ref name="Houdini!">{{cite book| author = Kenneth Silverman| title = Houdini! The Career of Ehrich Weiss: American Self-Liberator, Europe's Eclipsing Sensation, World's Handcuff King & Prison Breaker| year = October 1997| publisher = HarperCollins.|isbn=006092862X| page = 544}}</ref>
Society of American Magicians Hall of Fame and Magic Museum, [[Los Angeles]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Kawamoto |first=Wayne |url=http://magic.about.com/od/magicinthemedia/a/samhalloffame.htm |title=Closure Update: S.A.M. Hall of Fame and Magic Museum |website=Magic.about.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815235820/http://magic.about.com/od/magicinthemedia/a/samhalloffame.htm |archivedate=2016-08-15 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://magic.about.com/b/2006/12/12/call-to-save-magic-museum.htm|title=SAM Museum seeks benefactor|date=2006-12-12}}</ref> closed temporarily due to fire, contamination, and resultant litigation. After its disastrous fire, the museum's artifacts went on exhibit at the [[Jonathan Bailey House (Whittier, California)|Whittier Museum]] for six months beginning in September 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.magicnewzealand.com/ezine-archive/2012-Jan-to-Dec-2012/956-Sep16-2012.html |title=S.A.M. Hall Of Fame And Magic Museum Returns |first1=Michael |last1=Perovich |publisher=Magic New Zealand |date=September 16, 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref>
The organization pays tribute to [[Harry Houdini]], with a [[broken wand ceremony]] on the anniversary of his death (by the Jewish calendar)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magicsam.com/samnews.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070627104106/http://www.magicsam.com/samnews.asp |archivedate=2007-06-27 |df= }}</ref> at his grave in [[Machpelah Cemetery (Queens, New York)|Machpelah Cemetery]] in Ridgewood, Queens, New York City.
==The Society of Young Magicians== The Society of Young Magicians (SYM) is an organization devoted to assisting magicians, age seven through seventeen years. The Society of Young Magicians has clubs, known as "assemblies" located throughout the world; these assemblies are commonly jointly associated with an adult SAM assembly. When a member turns 18, they have the option to graduate to full membership in the Society of American Magicians.
The purpose of the Society of Young Magicians is to promote interest in [[Magic (illusion)|magic]] as a hobby that develops skill and self-confidence, the ability to speak in public, discipline that comes from learning, practicing and performing magic and a sense of service to others through helping others learn magic and by performing magic at charitable events.
The Society of Young Magicians has nearly 100 local chapters, or assemblies, around the world. Adult members of the Society of American Magicians supervise and instruct members of the SYM.
Dan Rodriguez is the SYM National Director. SYM's principal means of communication among its members is its e-zine, "The Magic SYMbol."
==Conventions== The S.A.M. national convention is held annually, usually over the Fourth of July weekend.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://magicsam.com/annual-convention/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140724062502/http://magicsam.com/annual-convention/ |archivedate=2014-07-24 |df= }}</ref>
==Publications== * In September 1902, ''[[Mahatma (magazine)|Mahatma]]'' became the official publication of S.A.M.<ref name="Alfredson">{{Cite book|url=http://askalexander.org/display/21976/A+Bibliography+of+Conjuring+Periodicals+in+English+1791+1983/250|title=A Bibliography of Conjuring Periodicals in English: 1791 – 1983|last=Alfredson|first=James B.|last2=Daily|first2=George L.|publisher=Magicana for Collectors|year=1986|isbn=|location=[[York, Pennsylvania]]|pages=230–31|subscription=yes}}</ref> * In November 1902, [[The Sphinx (magazine)|''The Sphinx'']] became the 'Western Organ' of S.A.M.<ref name="Alfredson 2">{{Cite book|url=http://askalexander.org/display/21976/A+Bibliography+of+Conjuring+Periodicals+in+English+1791+1983/348|title=A Bibliography of Conjuring Periodicals in English: 1791 – 1983|last=Alfredson|first=James B.|last2=Daily|first2=George L.|publisher=Magicana for Collectors|year=1986|isbn=|location=[[York, Pennsylvania]]|pages=328–30|subscription=yes}}</ref> * In March 1909, ''The Sphinx'' became the 'Official Organ' of S.A.M.<ref name="Alfredson 2" /> * In October 1911, S.A.M. started publishing ''M-U-M'', a monthly print magazine originally published independently until July 1927.<ref name="Alfredson" /> M-U-M stands for Magic, Unity, Might, a slogan of the S.A.M. * October 1927–February 1942 and July 1947–June 1951, ''M-U-M'' was published as part of ''The Sphinx''.<ref name="Alfredson 2" /> * March 1942–June 1947, ''M-U-M'' was published as part of ''Genii''.<ref name="Alfredson 2" /> * In June 1951, ''M-U-M'' became an independently published magazine again.<ref name="Alfredson" /> It is still in publication.
